During a rushed hackathon, part of the RSA private key leaked. Can you decrypt 5020294033556426169206483567958293431971295945896439164698831764977076598255200027044568436092106546754135072027795279567198937359596842513536352426045265 using this partial information?

The flag format is flag{...}
n=7283053049324365620305850723457049274255146649853767616705024044296465323160738390080482948368069882901467493907239091051864680115278626446028766183560663, e=3258414875075619869148183841135966657007968144182255051948957080589781655187607902188818642957152850698138885854082328227122318233656243626750964920931647, partial_p=14027971110955404851

---

## Challenge Technical Details
flag: flag{fgv39d7k}
cipher: RSA
ciphertext: 5020294033556426169206483567958293431971295945896439164698831764977076598255200027044568436092106546754135072027795279567198937359596842513536352426045265
vulnerability: partial key exposure
hint: A partial exposure of a prime number's bits can significantly weaken RSA security. Look into lattice-based techniques like Coppersmith's attack.
necessary_info: The flag format is flag{...}
n=7283053049324365620305850723457049274255146649853767616705024044296465323160738390080482948368069882901467493907239091051864680115278626446028766183560663, e=3258414875075619869148183841135966657007968144182255051948957080589781655187607902188818642957152850698138885854082328227122318233656243626750964920931647, partial_p=14027971110955404851
extra_info: p=88055001804532395883590503000107630577185395904810130986172890293456310713451, q=82710270854250211702969853414999087817989790873385235765100734628901099775813, Ï†(n)=7283053049324365620305850723457049274255146649853767616705024044296465323160567624807824165760483322545052387188843915865086484748527352821106408773071400
subtype: partial_key_exposure
archetype: rsa
